item.title: Egyptian Military Calls Toddler’s Life Sentence for Murder a Mistake
item.description: After an uproar over the conviction of the boy, Ahmed Mansour Qorani Sharara, the Egyptian military said that it was a case of mistaken identity.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: Blockade and Fuel Rationing End
item.description: Nepal ended five months of fuel rationing on Tuesday after persuading protesters to end a border blockade that cut oil supplies.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: C.D.C. Investigating 14 New Reports of Zika Transmission Through Sex
item.description: The agency said it was investigating new cases of transmission from male travelers to female partners and had confirmed two of them.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Two mosquitoes of the species aedes aegypti, which can spread Zika virus. The C.D.C. reported additional cases of sexual transmission of the disease on Tuesday.

item.title: Fernando Cardenal, Nicaraguan Priest Who Defied Pope, Dies at 82
item.description: Steeped in a movement committed to a Marxist agenda of promoting social justice and easing poverty, Father Cardenal joined the revolutionary Sandinista cabinet.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:credit: Dick Loek/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Fernando Cardenal in 1990. As education minister of Nicaragua under the Sandinistas in the 1980s, he oversaw a sweeping campaign credited with reducing illiteracy to 13 percent from 51 percent.

item.title: 30 Years After Revolution, Some Filipinos Yearn for ‘Golden Age’ of Marcos
item.description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., son of the former dictator, is leading his family’s political resurgence as the outrage that led to the 1986 “People Power” revolution fades.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:credit: Bernie Sipin Dela Cruz/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., a senator in the Philippines, campaigned for the vice presidency recently in Ilocos Norte Province.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Help Break Impasse and Restore Power to Kabul
item.description: Airstrikes on Taliban positions allowed repair crews to reach downed power lines and restore electricity to the Afghanistan capital after weeks of disruption, an official said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: The head of the United States delegation, David E. Lindwall, left, with Salahuddin Rabbani, Afghanistan’s foreign minister, during the fourth round of four-way peace talks at the presidential palace in Kabul on Tuesday.

item.title: Vaginal Ring With Drug Lowers H.I.V. Rates in African Women
item.description: A flexible ring that slowly releases an antiviral drug into the vagina helped protect African women against H.I.V. infection, two studies reported.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY
item.media:description: A dapivirine ring, inserted vaginally, was the subject of two studies on H.I.V. prevention that included more than 4,500 African women. Overall infection rates were reduced.

item.title: Russia Wants Closer Look From Above the U.S.
item.description: Russia has requested to upgrade the cameras it uses on sanctioned surveillance flights across the United States, which are part of a treaty.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Adm. Cecil D. Haney, commander of the United States Strategic Command, during a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing in Washington last year.

item.title: Macedonia Bars Afghan Asylum Seekers, Stoking Violent Clashes
item.description: The Greek riot police forcibly removed protesters from train tracks at a border camp after Macedonia blocked Afghans from seeking political asylum.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: An Afghan man pushing against the border fence during a demonstration on Monday near the Greek village of Idomeni, against Macedonia’s refusal to allow Afghans to pass the border.

item.title: Kurdish Fighters Rescue Swedish Teenager in Iraq
item.description: Marilyn Nevalainen, 16, was taken from Islamic-controlled territory near Mosul, Iraq, after traveling to Syria last summer.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: News Analysis: Questions Linger Over Russia’s Endgame in Syria, Ukraine and Europe
item.description: A partial truce in Syria capped something of a foreign policy trifecta for President Vladimir V. Putin, but his goals are uncertain for all three.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Tuesday. Mr. Putin hopes to break a consensus among the European Union’s 28 nations on economic sanctions imposed on Russia.

item.title: Government in Syria and Some Rebel Groups Agree to Partial Cease-Fire
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad and the umbrella group of opposition and rebel groups in Syria announced they would accept a new “cessation of hostilities.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrian government forces near Aleppo’s thermal power plant after they took control of the area on Sunday, driving out Islamic State militants.

item.title: John E. Reinhardt, Ambassador and Head of U.S. Information Agency, Dies at 95
item.description: Dr. Reinhardt was the first black American ambassador to Nigeria, and the first career diplomat and first university educator to lead the information agency.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Vice President Walter Mondale, left, and John E. Reinhardt in April 1978.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Russia and Germany Cling to Fragile Business Ties
item.description: Trade has dropped between the two countries, but some business leaders say they will keep talking and hope for better days.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia during an interview on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference this month.

item.title: Chongqing Journal: China Maintains Respect, and a Museum, for a U.S. General
item.description: In southwestern Chongqing, there is an unlikely memorial to an American, Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, who led the U.S. mission in China in World War II.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bust of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell of the United States Army outside the Stilwell Museum in Chongqing, China. William J. Perry, who was then the secretary of defense, came for the opening of the museum in 1994.

item.title: U.S. to Further Scour Social Media Use of Visa and Asylum Seekers
item.description: Experts say the effort faces technical, language and other hurdles, while immigration rights advocates say it could ensnare innocent people.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeh Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, this month. The department said it developed a list of situations where social media accounts could be examined to screen visa applicants and those seeking asylum or refugee status.

item.title: Possible Radar Suggests Beijing Wants ‘Effective Control’ in South China Sea
item.description: The report comes less than a week after the United States said that China appeared to have deployed missiles on another island in the disputed sea.
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: The People’s Liberation Army Navy patrolling on the Spratly Islands.

item.title: Sinosphere: Theft of Guide Dog Underlines China’s Spotty Disability Record
item.description: The stolen dog, Qiaoqiao, is one of about 10 registered guide dogs in Beijing, a city of more than 20 million, officials said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wu Wenhao, left, with her guide dog, Zi Long, in the Beijing subway. China enacted a law in 2012 allowing such dogs in public places, and last year, Beijing began allowing visually impaired passengers to take dogs into the subway.

item.title: Beijing to Raise Threshold on Red Alerts for Smog
item.description: The change in how the air quality alerts would be applied highlights officials’ worries about the social disruption they can cause.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO
item.media:description: Tiananmen Square during heavy pollution in Beijing in December.

item.title: Seas Are Rising at Fastest Rate in Last 28 Centuries
item.description: Scientists reported Monday that flooding in coastal communities was largely a result of greenhouse gas emissions, and likely to grow worse.
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Waves striking the promenade in San Sebastián, Spain, earlier this month. Scientists warned on Monday that flooding driven by climate change is likely to worsen in coming years.
